# Introduction

Every six years member states of the European Union have to report on the conservation status of species and habitat types listed on the Habitat and Bird Directive. The Nature and Forest Research Institute (INBO) is responsible for the monitoring of these species and habitat types in Flanders, the northern part of Belgium. 

INBO implemented a monitoring programme for habitat types that consists of following parts:

+ a field based habitat mapping campaign to assess the distribution, area and range of all habitat types and subtypes in Flanders

+ a monitoring scheme to assess the biotic habitat quality for most habitat types and subtypes

An additional part for monitoring the natural environment is currently under development. It aims at assessing the abiotic conditions of habitat types to evaluate pressures and threats. 

In this report, we will focus on the monitoring scheme for biotic habitat quality (MHQ) and we will evaluate the design of this scheme as described in @westra2014. We will first give a short summary of the [information needs](#information) and give an overview of some of the [characteristics of MHQ](#overview). Next we will [evaluate the sample size](#samplesize). The original sample size of the monitoring scheme is based on sample size calculations for the status of the habitat quality [@westra2014]. In this report we will also perform sample size calculations for the habitat quality trend, as trend information plays a more important role in the habitat reporting. Finally, we will evaluate some alternative scenarios for the monitoring design and document the modifications of the monitoring design that will be implemented. We do this separately for [terrestrial habitat types](#scenarioterr), [standing water habitat types](#scenariostandwater) and [stream habitat types](#scenariostream).
